title: Need help identifying/finding a font
content:
![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080907053436im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/sauvage_3711.gif)

Anyone know this font and/or where I can find it? Thanks!

 [‹ EURO2008 / Shirts and their fonts](http://web.archive.org/web/20080907053436/http:/www.typophile.com/node/44929 "Go to previous forum topic") [Decemberists Concert Poster typeface ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080907053436/http:/www.typophile.com/node/43789 "Go to next forum topic")
author: lipps

comments.content: Nobody? I guess it is a really hard one?
Reminds me of Binner condensed. But it isn’t.

This is an old Letraset lowercase-only font called Camellia that had both wide and narrow versions of every letter. There is a digital version by that name, but it only has the wide letters. The missing narrow letters match your sample.

[http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/camellia-lt/](http://web.archive.org/web/20080907053436/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/camellia-lt/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/camellia-lt/")
Thanks! It does look very close. However, even in a thinner version, the ’s’ and ’v’ do not look like they would match. Would they be styled different in a thinner version?

You’re right about the ’v’, I hadn’t noticed that before. As you can see in this scan from an old Letraset catalog, everything else matches:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080907053436im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/camellia001_6109.jpg)

Perhaps the ’v’ was modified because it looked too much like the ’u’.

Yup, it looks like a perfect match except for the ’v’. Now where can I get a digital copy of the lowercase letters? :)

Thanks much!

[Opti Christie](http://web.archive.org/web/20080907053436/http:/www.castcraft-software.com/designer4/designer4.03.html) had the Camellia lowercase. I don’t have the font or a full showing, so don’t know about that ’v’, though.
Thanks, I’ll give them a try!
